title: Irrational and Real Numbers
content:
Module 1, Lesson 4: Irrational and Real Numbers

The Hook

Not all numbers are rational. Numbers like √2, √3, π, and e cannot be expressed as fractions of integers — they are irrational. The real numbers ℝ = ℚ ∪ {irrationals} form a complete ordered field that corresponds exactly to points on the number line.

The Concept

1. Proving Irrationality

The classic proof that √2 is irrational uses proof by contradiction. Assume √2 = p/q in lowest terms. Then 2q² = p², so p is even (p = 2m). Substituting gives 2q² = 4m², so q² = 2m², meaning q is also even — contradicting p/q being in lowest terms.

2. Properties of Real Numbers

The reals form a complete ordered field: between any two real numbers there exists another real number (density), and every non-empty set bounded above has a least upper bound (completeness). These properties are what make calculus work.

3. Number Line Representation

Every real number corresponds to a unique point on the number line, and every point corresponds to a unique real number. This one-to-one correspondence is essential for geometry and analysis.

4. Special Constants

π ≈ 3.14159 (ratio of circle circumference to diameter) and e ≈ 2.71828 (base of natural logarithm) are transcendental — not only irrational but also not roots of any polynomial with rational coefficients.

The Illustration

You explored irrational and real numbers, learned to prove irrationality by contradiction, and understood the completeness property that distinguishes ℝ from ℚ.
